segments.pli: Saṃyutta Nikāya 17
segments.en: Linked Discourses 17

segments.pli: 1. Paṭhamavagga
segments.en: 1. The First Chapter

segments.pli: 3. Kummasutta
segments.en: 3. A Turtle

segments.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ viharati.
segments.en: At Sāvatthī.

segments.pli: “Dāruṇo, bhikkhave, lābhasakkārasiloko … pe … adhigamāya.
segments.en: “Possessions, honor, and popularity are brutal …

segments.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, aññatarasmiṃ udakarahade mahākummakulaṃ ciranivāsi ahosi.
segments.en: Once upon a time in a certain lake there was a large family of turtles that had lived there for a long time.

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, aññataro kummo aññataraṃ kummaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then one of the turtles said to another,

segments.pli: ‘mā kho tvaṃ, tāta kumma, etaṃ padesaṃ agamāsī’ti.
segments.en: ‘My dear turtle, don’t you go to that place.’

segments.pli: Agamāsi kho, bhikkhave, so kummo taṃ padesaṃ.
segments.en: But that turtle did go to that place,

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ luddo papatāya vijjhi.
segments.en: and a hunter pierced her with a harpoon.

segments.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, so kummo yena so kummo tenupasaṅkami.
segments.en: Then that turtle went back to the other turtle.

segments.pli: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, so kummo taṃ kummaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
segments.en: When the other turtle saw her coming off in the distance,

segments.pli: Disvāna taṃ kummaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: he said,

segments.pli: ‘kacci tvaṃ, tāta kumma, na taṃ padesaṃ agamāsī’ti?
segments.en: ‘My dear turtle, I hope you didn’t go to that place!’

segments.pli: ‘Agamāsiṃ khvāhaṃ, tāta kumma, taṃ padesan’ti.
segments.en: ‘I did.’

segments.pli: ‘Kacci panāsi, tāta kumma, akkhato anupahato’ti?
segments.en: ‘But my dear turtle, I hope you’re not hurt or injured!’

segments.pli: ‘Akkhato khomhi, tāta kumma, anupahato, atthi ca me idaṃ suttakaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhan’ti.
segments.en: ‘I’m not hurt or injured. But this cord keeps dragging behind me.’

segments.pli: ‘Tagghasi, tāta kumma, khato, taggha upahato.
segments.en: ‘Indeed, my dear turtle, you’re hurt and injured!

segments.pli: Etena hi te, tāta kumma, suttakena pitaro ca pitāmahā ca anayaṃ āpannā byasanaṃ āpannā.
segments.en: Your father and grandfather met with tragedy and disaster because of such a cord.

segments.pli: Gaccha dāni tvaṃ, tāta kumma, na dāni tvaṃ amhākan’ti.
segments.en: Go now, you are no longer one of us.’

segments.pli: Luddoti kho, bhikkhave, mārassetaṃ pāpimato adhivacanaṃ.
segments.en: ‘Hunter’ is a term for Māra the Wicked.

segments.pli: Papatāti kho, bhikkhave, lābhasakkārasilokassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
segments.en: ‘Harpoon’ is a term for possessions, honor, and popularity.

segments.pli: Suttakanti kho, bhikkhave, nandīrāgassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
segments.en: ‘Cord’ is a term for desire with relishing.

segments.pli: Yo hi koci, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uppannaṃ lābhasakkārasilokaṃ assādeti nikāmeti—
segments.en: Whoever enjoys and likes arisen possessions, honor, and popularity is called a mendicant who has been pierced with a harpoon. They’ve met with tragedy and disaster, and the Wicked One can treat them however he wants.

segments.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, bhikkhu giddho papatāya anayaṃ āpanno byasanaṃ āpanno yathākāmakaraṇīyo pāpimato.
Evaṃ dāruṇo kho, bhikkhave, lābhasakkārasiloko … pe …
segments.en: So brutal are possessions, honor, and popularity. …”

segments.pli: evañhi vo, bhikkhave, sikkhitabban”ti.
Tatiyaṃ.

suttaplex.blurb: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which hit you like a harpoon hits a careless turtle.
